cards.front: When did Canada become a country?
cards.trivia: The four original provinces were Ontario, Quebec, Nova Scotia, and New Brunswick. July 1 was originally called Dominion Day until 1982.

cards.front: When was the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms enacted?
cards.trivia: Queen Elizabeth II signed the proclamation in Ottawa. It was part of the Constitution Act that patriated Canada's constitution from Britain.

cards.front: When was the current Canadian flag first raised?
cards.trivia: The flag was first raised on February 15, 1965. Before this, Canada used the Red Ensign featuring the Union Jack.

cards.front: When did women first get the right to vote in federal elections?
cards.trivia: Manitoba was the first province to grant women the vote in 1916. Quebec was the last province, granting it in 1940.

cards.front: When was the Canadian Pacific Railway completed?
cards.trivia: Donald Smith (Lord Strathcona) drove the famous last spike at Craigellachie, BC. The railway united the country from coast to coast.

cards.front: When was the Battle of Vimy Ridge?
cards.trivia: This was the first time all four Canadian divisions fought together. Over 10,600 Canadians were killed or wounded in just four days.

cards.front: When is Remembrance Day?
cards.trivia: The date marks the armistice that ended WWI in 1918. Over 110,000 Canadians have died in military service since Confederation.

cards.front: When is Canada Day?
cards.trivia: It was called Dominion Day until 1982 when it was renamed Canada Day as part of the constitution patriation celebrations.

cards.front: When was the Magna Carta signed?
cards.trivia: Only four original copies survive today. The Magna Carta established that everyone, including the king, is subject to the law.

cards.front: When was the Official Languages Act passed?
cards.trivia: The act guaranteed English and French services in federal institutions. New Brunswick is the only officially bilingual province.

cards.front: When did Newfoundland and Labrador join Canada?
cards.trivia: It was the last province to join Confederation and did so by a narrow margin in a referendum: 52% voted to join Canada.

cards.front: When did Nunavut become a territory?
cards.trivia: Nunavut means 'our land' in Inuktitut. It was carved from the Northwest Territories and is about 85% Inuit population.

cards.front: When was the Quebec Act passed?
cards.trivia: This British act allowed French Canadians to practice Catholicism and use French civil law, helping to secure their loyalty.

cards.front: When did the War of 1812 take place?
cards.trivia: British forces burned down the White House in Washington, D.C. in 1814. The war ensured Canada would remain independent from the USA.

cards.front: When was D-Day?
cards.trivia: About 15,000 Canadian troops landed at Juno Beach. One in 10 Allied soldiers on D-Day was Canadian.

cards.front: When was O Canada proclaimed as the national anthem?
cards.trivia: O Canada was first sung in Quebec City on June 24, 1880, exactly 100 years before becoming the official anthem.

cards.front: When did Vikings first reach Canada?
cards.trivia: The Vikings established a settlement at L'Anse aux Meadows in Newfoundland, now a UNESCO World Heritage site.

cards.front: When was Quebec City founded?
cards.trivia: Samuel de Champlain built a fortress there, making it the first permanent French settlement in North America.

cards.front: When was the Battle of the Plains of Abraham?
cards.trivia: Both commanding generals, British General Wolfe and French General Montcalm, died in the battle. It decided the fate of New France.

cards.front: When was the Red River Rebellion?
cards.trivia: Led by Louis Riel, it resulted in the creation of Manitoba. Riel is considered the founder of Manitoba.

cards.front: When did Canada sign free trade with the United States?
cards.trivia: This was one of the most controversial elections in Canadian history. The agreement later expanded to include Mexico with NAFTA.

cards.front: When did NAFTA come into effect?
cards.trivia: NAFTA created one of the world's largest free trade zones with over 444 million people. It was replaced by USMCA in 2020.

cards.front: Who was Canada's first Prime Minister?
cards.trivia: He served for 19 years total and championed the Canadian Pacific Railway. His birthday, January 11, was once a national holiday.

cards.front: Who was the first French-Canadian Prime Minister since Confederation?
cards.trivia: He served for 15 years (1896-1911) and encouraged massive immigration to settle the West. His image appears on the $5 bill.

cards.front: Who discovered insulin?
cards.back: Sir Frederick Banting and Charles Best
cards.trivia: Banting sold the patent for $1 so insulin would be available to everyone. He won the Nobel Prize in 1923 at age 32.

cards.front: Who was Sir George-Etienne Cartier?
cards.back: A key architect of Confederation from Quebec
cards.trivia: He worked alongside Macdonald to unite Canada and was instrumental in bringing Quebec into Confederation.

cards.front: Who was Sir Louis-Hippolyte La Fontaine?
cards.back: Champion of democracy and French language rights, first leader of responsible government in the Canadas
cards.trivia: He worked with Robert Baldwin to achieve responsible government in 1848, a model for the British Empire.

cards.front: Who was Jacques Cartier?
cards.back: First European to explore the St. Lawrence River (1534-1542)
cards.trivia: He heard the Iroquoian word 'kanata' meaning village, which eventually became 'Canada' on maps by the 1550s.

cards.front: Who was John Cabot?
cards.back: First European to map Canada's Atlantic shore (1497)
cards.trivia: Italian-born Cabot sailed for England and claimed 'New Founde Land' for King Henry VII.

cards.front: Who was Laura Secord?
cards.back: Pioneer who warned British forces of American attack in 1813
cards.trivia: She walked 30 km through rough terrain to deliver her warning. A famous chocolate company is named after her.

cards.front: Who was Terry Fox?
cards.back: Young Canadian who ran across Canada for cancer research (Marathon of Hope)
cards.trivia: His Marathon of Hope has raised over $850 million worldwide. He ran 5,373 km on one leg before cancer forced him to stop.

cards.front: Who invented the telephone?
cards.back: Alexander Graham Bell (at his summer house in Canada)
cards.trivia: Bell made the first long-distance call from Brantford to Paris, Ontario in 1876. He became a Canadian citizen.

cards.front: Who invented the snowmobile?
cards.trivia: Bombardier Inc. grew from his Quebec garage workshop into a global aerospace and transportation company.

cards.front: Who invented standard time zones?
cards.trivia: He proposed the worldwide system of time zones in 1879 after missing a train due to confusing local times.

cards.front: Who was Wayne Gretzky?
cards.back: One of the greatest hockey players of all time
cards.trivia: He holds 61 NHL records and is nicknamed 'The Great One.' His jersey number 99 is retired league-wide.

cards.front: Who was Agnes Macphail?
cards.trivia: She served for 19 years and was a champion of prison reform and farmers' rights.

cards.front: Who is Canada's Head of State?
cards.trivia: Canada is the only constitutional monarchy in North America. The monarch's role is largely ceremonial.

cards.front: Who was Samuel de Champlain?
cards.back: Founder of Quebec City and 'Father of New France'
cards.trivia: He made over 20 voyages across the Atlantic and created detailed maps that were used for centuries.

cards.front: Who were Generals Wolfe and Montcalm?
cards.back: British and French commanders who both died at the Battle of the Plains of Abraham (1759)
cards.trivia: Their deaths in the same battle is one of history's great ironies. A joint monument honors them in Quebec City.

cards.front: Who was Louis Riel?
cards.back: Metis leader who led two uprisings and founded Manitoba
cards.trivia: He was executed for treason in 1885 but is now considered a Father of Confederation by many. Manitoba has a statutory holiday in his honor.

cards.front: Who was General Sir Arthur Currie?
cards.back: Canadian commander who led the Corps to victory in WWI's final hundred days
cards.trivia: He was the first Canadian to command the Canadian Corps and never lost a battle. He's considered one of WWI's best generals.

cards.front: Who wrote 'In Flanders Fields'?
cards.trivia: He wrote the poem in 1915 after presiding over a friend's funeral. It inspired the poppy as a symbol of remembrance.

cards.front: Who invented basketball?
cards.trivia: The Canadian-born Naismith invented the game in 1891 in Massachusetts using a peach basket and soccer ball.

cards.front: What is the capital of Canada?
cards.trivia: Queen Victoria chose Ottawa as the capital in 1857, partly because it was far from the American border and between English and French Canada.

cards.front: Capital of Ontario
cards.trivia: Toronto is Canada's largest city and financial hub. It has the largest population of any city in Canada with over 6 million in the metro area.

cards.front: Capital of Quebec
cards.trivia: Quebec City is the oldest walled city in North America north of Mexico. Its old town is a UNESCO World Heritage site.

cards.front: Capital of British Columbia
cards.trivia: Victoria is on Vancouver Island, not the mainland. It has the mildest climate in Canada with flowers blooming year-round.

cards.front: Capital of Alberta
cards.trivia: Edmonton is known as the 'Gateway to the North' and hosts the West Edmonton Mall, once the world's largest shopping mall.

cards.front: Capital of Saskatchewan
cards.trivia: Regina was named after Queen Victoria (Regina is Latin for 'queen'). It's home to the RCMP training academy.

cards.front: Capital of Manitoba
cards.trivia: Winnipeg is called the 'Gateway to the West' and is almost exactly in the geographic center of North America.

cards.front: Capital of Nova Scotia
cards.trivia: Halifax has one of the world's largest natural harbors. The Halifax Explosion of 1917 was the largest man-made explosion before the atomic bomb.

cards.front: Capital of New Brunswick
cards.trivia: Fredericton is the only officially bilingual provincial capital, as New Brunswick is Canada's only bilingual province.

cards.front: Capital of Prince Edward Island
cards.trivia: Charlottetown is called the 'Birthplace of Confederation' because the 1864 conference that led to Canada was held there.

cards.front: Capital of Newfoundland and Labrador
cards.trivia: St. John's is the oldest and easternmost city in North America. It's closer to Ireland than to Winnipeg.

cards.front: Capital of Yukon
cards.trivia: Whitehorse has the least precipitation of any Canadian capital and was a supply point during the Klondike Gold Rush.

cards.front: Capital of Northwest Territories
cards.trivia: Yellowknife is called the 'Diamond Capital of North America' due to nearby diamond mines discovered in the 1990s.

cards.front: Capital of Nunavut
cards.trivia: Iqaluit means 'place of fish' in Inuktitut. It became the capital when Nunavut was created in 1999.

cards.front: What are the three parts of Parliament?
cards.back: The Sovereign, the Senate, and the House of Commons
cards.trivia: All three parts must agree for a bill to become law. The Sovereign's role is performed by the Governor General.

cards.front: What type of government does Canada have?
cards.back: Constitutional monarchy, parliamentary democracy, and federal state
cards.trivia: Canada is the only constitutional monarchy in North America and has used this system since Confederation in 1867.

cards.front: Who is the Head of Government?
cards.trivia: The PM is not directly elected but is the leader of the party with the most seats. Canada has had 23 Prime Ministers.

cards.front: Who represents the Sovereign in Canada?
cards.trivia: The Governor General is appointed on the advice of the Prime Minister, typically for a five-year term.

cards.front: Who represents the Sovereign in each province?
cards.trivia: Lieutenant Governors perform similar duties to the Governor General but at the provincial level. They are federally appointed.

cards.front: What is responsible government?
cards.back: Ministers must have the support of a majority of elected representatives to govern
cards.trivia: Canada achieved responsible government in 1848, the first British colony to do so. It was a model for the Commonwealth.

cards.front: How many provinces and territories does Canada have?
cards.trivia: Provinces have powers guaranteed by the Constitution, while territories get their powers from the federal government.

cards.front: What are the three levels of government?
cards.trivia: Municipal governments handle local matters like garbage, water, and local roads. They get their power from provinces.

cards.front: What is a majority government?
cards.back: When the party in power holds at least half the seats in the House of Commons
cards.trivia: Majority governments can pass legislation more easily since they control enough votes to win any vote.

cards.front: What is a minority government?
cards.back: When the party in power holds less than half the seats in the House of Commons
cards.trivia: Minority governments must work with opposition parties to pass laws and can be defeated on confidence votes.

cards.front: How are senators appointed?
cards.back: By the Governor General on the advice of the Prime Minister
cards.trivia: The Senate was designed to represent regional interests and provide 'sober second thought' on legislation.

cards.front: How long do senators serve?
cards.trivia: Before 1965, senators served for life. The mandatory retirement age was added to ensure regular turnover.

cards.front: How many electoral districts (ridings) are in Canada?
cards.trivia: Each riding elects one Member of Parliament. The number is adjusted after each census based on population.

cards.front: Who represents the federal government in territories?
cards.trivia: Unlike provinces which have Lieutenant Governors representing the Crown, territories have Commissioners representing the federal government.

cards.front: How many readings must a bill pass to become law?
cards.back: Three readings in each chamber, plus Royal Assent
cards.trivia: Bills must pass three readings in both the House of Commons and Senate before receiving Royal Assent from the Governor General.

cards.front: What is Canada's national anthem?
cards.trivia: It was originally composed in French for Saint-Jean-Baptiste Day in Quebec City in 1880.

cards.front: What are Canada's national colours?
cards.trivia: Red and white were declared Canada's official colours by King George V in 1921.

cards.front: What is Canada's best-known symbol?
cards.trivia: The maple leaf has been a Canadian symbol since the 1700s. Canadian soldiers wore maple leaf badges since the Boer War.

cards.front: What is Canada's national winter sport?
cards.trivia: Hockey was declared the official winter sport in 1994. The first organized indoor game was played in Montreal in 1875.

cards.front: What is Canada's national summer sport?
cards.trivia: Lacrosse originated with Indigenous peoples and was adopted by European settlers. It was declared the national sport in 1994.

cards.front: What does the national motto 'A Mari Usque Ad Mare' mean?
cards.trivia: The motto comes from Psalm 72:8 and refers to Canada stretching from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean.

cards.front: What animal is an official symbol of Canada?
cards.trivia: The beaver was nearly hunted to extinction for the fur trade. It appears on the nickel and many coats of arms.

cards.front: What is the Victoria Cross?
cards.back: The highest honour for bravery available to Canadians
cards.trivia: 96 Canadians have received the Victoria Cross since 1854. The medal is made from Russian cannon captured in the Crimean War.

cards.front: What is the fleur-de-lys?
cards.back: Symbol of French royalty, appears on Quebec's flag
cards.trivia: The fleur-de-lys represented the French Crown for over 1,000 years. Quebec adopted it on their flag in 1948.

cards.front: What is the Royal Anthem?
cards.trivia: The Royal Anthem is played when the Sovereign or their representative is present at official ceremonies.

cards.front: How many Canadians have received the Victoria Cross?
cards.trivia: The Victoria Cross was created by Queen Victoria in 1856 and is awarded for extreme bravery in the face of the enemy.

cards.front: When was the Order of Canada established?
cards.trivia: The Order of Canada recognizes outstanding achievement and service to the country. The snowflake-shaped medal features a maple leaf.

cards.front: What are Canada's two official languages?
cards.trivia: About 18 million Canadians speak English as a first language and 7 million speak French. New Brunswick is the only officially bilingual province.

cards.front: Name three citizenship responsibilities
cards.back: Obeying the law, taking responsibility for oneself and family, serving on a jury
cards.trivia: Jury duty is the only legally mandatory responsibility. Voting and helping others in the community are moral duties.

cards.front: What is habeas corpus?
cards.back: The right to challenge unlawful detention by the state
cards.trivia: This right comes from English common law and is over 800 years old. It protects against arbitrary imprisonment.

cards.front: What does the Magna Carta represent?
cards.trivia: The Magna Carta established that even the king must follow the law. Only four original copies survive today.

cards.front: What are four fundamental freedoms in Canada?
cards.back: Freedom of conscience/religion, thought/expression, peaceful assembly, and association
cards.trivia: These freedoms are protected by the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, which is part of Canada's Constitution.

cards.front: What does Mobility Rights mean?
cards.back: Canadians can live and work anywhere in Canada, enter/leave freely, apply for passport
cards.trivia: These rights allow Canadians to move between provinces without restriction, unlike in some federal countries.

cards.front: What does presumption of innocence mean?
cards.back: Everyone is innocent until proven guilty
cards.trivia: The burden of proof is on the prosecution. This principle is fundamental to the Canadian justice system.

cards.front: Who can vote in federal elections?
cards.trivia: About 27 million Canadians are eligible to vote. Indigenous peoples gained the right to vote without losing status in 1960.

cards.front: What is a secret ballot?
cards.back: No one can watch you vote or see how you voted
cards.trivia: The secret ballot protects voters from pressure or intimidation. It has been used in Canada since 1874.

cards.front: Which are the Atlantic Provinces?
cards.back: Newfoundland and Labrador, Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick
cards.trivia: The Atlantic provinces have the smallest populations but some of the oldest European settlements in North America.

cards.front: Which are the Prairie Provinces?
cards.trivia: The prairies produce most of Canada's wheat and grain. Saskatchewan alone has 40% of Canada's farmland.

cards.front: Which is the smallest province?
cards.trivia: PEI is so small you can drive across it in about 2 hours. It's famous for red sand beaches and Anne of Green Gables.

cards.front: Which province is the birthplace of Confederation?
cards.trivia: The 1864 Charlottetown Conference that led to Confederation was held there, giving PEI this honorary title.

cards.front: Which is the only officially bilingual province?
cards.trivia: About one-third of New Brunswickers speak French as their first language, mostly Acadians.

cards.front: What is the largest freshwater lake in the world?
cards.trivia: Lake Superior contains 10% of the world's surface fresh water. It's so large it creates its own weather systems.

cards.front: What is the highest mountain in Canada?
cards.trivia: At 5,959 meters, Mount Logan is the second-highest peak in North America after Denali.

cards.front: What are the five Great Lakes?
cards.trivia: The Great Lakes contain 20% of the world's fresh surface water. Only Lake Michigan is entirely in the United States.

cards.front: What province has the world's highest tides?
cards.trivia: Tides in the Bay of Fundy can rise over 16 meters (53 feet), enough to flood a five-story building.

cards.front: What is the 'Land of the Midnight Sun'?
cards.trivia: In summer, the sun doesn't set for weeks in the far north. In winter, there are weeks of near-total darkness.

cards.front: How large is Canada?
cards.back: About 10 million square kilometers (second largest country)
cards.trivia: Canada is the second-largest country by total area, after Russia. It spans six time zones.

cards.front: When was Ottawa chosen as Canada's capital?
cards.trivia: Ottawa was chosen partly because it was far from the US border and located between English Ontario and French Quebec.

cards.front: What city is called the 'Diamond Capital of North America'?
cards.trivia: Diamond mines discovered in the 1990s near Yellowknife made Canada one of the world's top diamond producers.

cards.front: What is Canada's largest and busiest port?
cards.trivia: The Port of Vancouver handles over 140 million tonnes of cargo annually, connecting Canada to markets across the Pacific.

cards.front: Who are Canada's three founding peoples?
cards.trivia: The Constitution recognizes these three groups. Aboriginal peoples have been in Canada for at least 12,000 years.

cards.front: What are the three Aboriginal groups?
cards.trivia: Each group has distinct cultures, languages, and histories. Together they make up about 5% of Canada's population.

cards.front: What does 'Inuit' mean?
cards.trivia: The word 'Eskimo' is considered outdated and sometimes offensive. Inuit is the preferred term for Arctic indigenous peoples.

cards.front: Who are the Metis?
cards.back: A distinct people of mixed Aboriginal and European ancestry
cards.trivia: The Metis developed their own language (Michif), culture, and way of life, primarily in the Prairie provinces.

cards.front: What percentage of Aboriginal people are First Nations?
cards.trivia: There are over 630 First Nations communities in Canada, speaking more than 50 distinct languages.

cards.front: What language do the Metis speak?
cards.trivia: Michif is a unique language mixing French nouns with Cree verbs. It's now endangered with only a few thousand speakers.

cards.front: What was the Royal Proclamation of 1763?
cards.trivia: The proclamation recognized Aboriginal title to lands and required treaties for settlement. It's still referenced in land claims today.

cards.front: What territory has the highest Inuit population?
cards.trivia: Nunavut was created in 1999 specifically to give Inuit more control over their homeland and traditions.

cards.front: What does 'Nunavut' mean?
cards.trivia: Nunavut is the largest and newest Canadian territory, covering about 20% of Canada's land area.

cards.front: How many First Nations reserve communities are in Canada?
cards.trivia: Reserves are lands set aside for First Nations under the Indian Act. Some are very small, others cover thousands of square kilometers.

cards.front: Who are the Acadians?
cards.back: French descendants who survived the Great Upheaval (1755-1763)
cards.trivia: The British expelled thousands of Acadians from Nova Scotia. Many went to Louisiana, where they became known as Cajuns.

cards.front: How often are federal elections held?
cards.back: Every four years, on the third Monday in October
cards.trivia: The Prime Minister can ask the Governor General to call an earlier election if needed.

cards.front: What are the requirements to vote in Canada?
cards.back: Canadian citizen, 18 or older, on the voters list
cards.trivia: Elections Canada maintains the National Register of Electors, a permanent database of eligible voters.

cards.front: How do you mark your ballot?
cards.back: Mark an X in the circle next to your chosen candidate's name
cards.trivia: Ballots are paper and hand-counted. This system is considered very reliable and resistant to tampering.

cards.front: What are the three main federal political parties?
cards.back: Conservative, Liberal, and New Democratic Party (NDP)
cards.trivia: Canada has had a multi-party system since Confederation. Other parties include the Bloc Quebecois and Green Party.

cards.front: What is the Official Opposition?
cards.back: The party with the second-most seats in Parliament
cards.trivia: The Official Opposition's job is to hold the government accountable and propose alternatives to government policies.

cards.front: Can you run for Parliament if you're a citizen?
cards.back: Yes, Canadian citizens 18 or older can run as candidates
cards.trivia: Candidates don't need to live in the riding they represent, though most do.

cards.front: Is voting mandatory in Canada?
cards.back: No, voting is voluntary but considered a civic duty
cards.trivia: Voter turnout in federal elections is typically between 60-70%. Some countries like Australia have mandatory voting.

cards.front: Are you required to tell anyone how you voted?
cards.back: No, voting is by secret ballot
cards.trivia: The secret ballot was introduced in Canada in 1874 to prevent voter intimidation and vote-buying.

cards.front: What is the highest court in Canada?
cards.trivia: The Supreme Court has nine justices and hears about 80 cases per year. Their decisions are final and binding.

cards.front: What does 'rule of law' mean?
cards.back: Everyone, including government, must follow the law
cards.trivia: No one is above the law in Canada, not even the Prime Minister or judges. This principle dates back to the Magna Carta.

cards.front: What is the RCMP?
cards.back: Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the federal and national police force
cards.trivia: The RCMP evolved from the North West Mounted Police, founded in 1873. The iconic red serge uniform is recognized worldwide.

cards.front: Which provinces have their own provincial police?
cards.trivia: In other provinces, the RCMP provides provincial policing services under contract with the provincial government.

cards.front: Can you question police about their conduct in Canada?
cards.back: Yes, most police forces have a complaints process
cards.trivia: Civilian oversight of police is an important part of Canadian democracy and helps maintain public trust.

cards.front: What is the purpose of courts in Canada?
cards.back: To settle disputes and determine guilt in criminal cases fairly
cards.trivia: Judges are independent and cannot be fired by the government, ensuring they can make decisions without political pressure.

cards.front: Where does Canada rank among world economies?
cards.trivia: Canada is a member of the G7 (formerly G8) group of the world's largest advanced economies.

cards.front: Who is Canada's largest trading partner?
cards.trivia: Over 75% of Canadian exports go to the US. The Canada-US trade relationship is the largest bilateral trade relationship in the world.

cards.front: What percentage of Canadians work in service industries?
cards.trivia: Service industries include healthcare, education, retail, banking, and government. Manufacturing has declined as a share of employment.

cards.front: What are Canada's main exports?
cards.back: Energy, automotive products, machinery, forestry, and agricultural products
cards.trivia: Canada is one of the world's largest exporters of oil, natural gas, and hydroelectric power.

cards.front: When was free trade with the US established?
cards.trivia: The Free Trade Agreement was controversial and was the main issue in the 1988 federal election.

cards.front: What trade agreement includes Canada, US, and Mexico?
cards.trivia: NAFTA came into effect in 1994 and was replaced by USMCA in 2020. It covers over 500 million people.

cards.front: When was oil discovered in Alberta?
cards.trivia: The Leduc oil strike launched Alberta's modern oil industry. Alberta now produces most of Canada's oil and gas.

cards.front: What ensures healthcare standards across Canada?
cards.trivia: The act ensures all Canadians have access to medically necessary hospital and physician services without paying out of pocket.

cards.front: When was Employment Insurance (EI) introduced?
cards.trivia: Originally called Unemployment Insurance, it provides temporary income support to workers who lose their jobs.

cards.front: When was Old Age Security established?
cards.trivia: OAS is available to most Canadians 65 and older who meet residency requirements. It's funded through general tax revenue.

cards.front: When were the Canada and Quebec Pension Plans created?
cards.trivia: CPP and QPP are funded by contributions from workers and employers. Quebec operates its own plan separately.

cards.front: What war did Canada fight in from 1950-1953?
cards.trivia: About 26,000 Canadians served in Korea. 516 Canadians died and over 1,000 were wounded.

cards.front: What military alliances is Canada part of?
cards.trivia: NATO protects North Atlantic members, while NORAD is a joint US-Canada aerospace defense command.

cards.front: What was the Quiet Revolution?
cards.trivia: Quebec rapidly secularized and modernized its economy, education, and healthcare during this peaceful transformation.

cards.front: When were Quebec sovereignty referendums held?
cards.trivia: Both referendums failed, but the 1995 vote was extremely close with 50.58% voting No.

cards.front: Who invented the cardiac pacemaker?
cards.trivia: Hopps invented the first external pacemaker in 1950 at the National Research Council of Canada.

cards.front: What is the Canadarm?
cards.back: A robotic arm used on space shuttles and the space station
cards.trivia: The Canadarm was Canada's contribution to NASA's Space Shuttle program. Canadarm2 is still used on the International Space Station.
